title: About
text:
This workshop was developed for the Young Investigators Symposium of the Skintegrity Network to introduce researchers to bulk RNA-seq data analysis using R and Bioconductor. It focuses on practical understanding and hands-on application of fundamental analysis steps, from data import to differential expression and enrichment analysis.


This workshop is designed for: - Researchers with little or no prior experience in RNA-seq analysis - Students and early-stage postdocs in the biomedical/life sciences - Participants who have basic familiarity with R (e.g., creating variables, loading packages)



RNA-seq is a powerful tool for understanding gene expression changes in health and disease. Differential expression analysis is the most common type of analysis for RNA-seq data.



This is a one-day introductory course combining:
‚úÖ Short presentations for conceptual understanding
‚úÖ Step-by-step guided exercises in R
‚úÖ Group discussion and Q&A



The material is adapted and simplified from the Carpentries Incubator course
‚ÄúRNA-seq Analysis with Bioconductor‚Äù (https://carpentries-incubator.github.io/bioc-rnaseq/).



This work is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC-BY 4.0).
You are free to:
- Share ‚Äî copy and redistribute the material in any medium or format
- Adapt ‚Äî remix, transform, and build upon the material
Under the following term: - Attribution ‚Äî You must give appropriate credit to the original authors and source (this workshop and The Carpentries RNA-seq course), provide a link to the license, and indicate if changes were made.
Full license text: https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/

title: Single Cell: Preprocessing and QC
text:
library(Seurat)
epi <- readRDS("data/epithelial_bcc_and_normal_seurat.rds")
epi

title: Single Cell: Preprocessing and QC
text:
Filtering of Cells
Quality metrics are:

The number of unique genes detected in each cell.
Total number of molecules detected within a cell (correlates strongly with unique genes)
The percentage of reads that map to the mitochondrial genome

The example object already contains all 3 quality metrics. Seurat automatically does so for the number of unique genes and detected molecules per cell, but usually the mitochondrial genes have to be calculated. Here this can be skipped.

Exercise 1: Visualize different cell quality metrics
# epi[["percent.mt"]] <- PercentageFeatureSet(epi, pattern = "^MT-")

# Visualize QC metrics as a violin plot
Seurat::VlnPlot(epi, features = c("nFeature_RNA", "nCount_RNA", "percent.mt"), ncol = 3)
Question: How are the different groups affected by the quality metrics? How does this affect downstream analysis?
Question: Can you explain the sharp cut-off for some metrics and groups, e.g.¬†2500 unique features for the bcc group?

title: Single Cell: Preprocessing and QC
text:
Normalizing the Data

Exercise 2: Log-Normalization
This object contains already normalized data. So we don‚Äôt have to run normalization again.
SeuratObject::Layers(epi)
# epi <- Seurat::NormalizeData(epi)

title: Single Cell: Preprocessing and QC
text:
Feature Selection

Exercise 3: Identify highly variable features
epi <- Seurat::FindVariableFeatures(epi,selection.method = "vst", nfeatures = 2000)

# top10 variable features:
top10 <- head(Seurat::VariableFeatures(epi), 10)

# plot variable features with and without labels
plot1 <- Seurat::VariableFeaturePlot(epi)
Seurat::LabelPoints(plot = plot1, points = top10, repel = TRUE)
Question: What are the top variable genes? Can you explain the plot?

title: Single Cell: Preprocessing and QC
text:
Scaling
The ScaleData()function:

Shifts the expression of each gene, so that the mean is 0 and variance is 1
Accounts for mean expression in downstream tasks
By default, only variable features are scaled
Can be used to remove unwanted sources of variation (vars.to.regress)


Exercise 4: Scaling the data
epi <- Seurat::ScaleData(epi, vars.to.regress = "percent.mt")

title: Single Cell: Preprocessing and QC
text:
Dimensional Reduction

Exercise 5: Run PCA and examine the loadings
epi <- Seurat::RunPCA(epi, features = Seurat::VariableFeatures(object = epi))
Seurat::VizDimLoadings(epi, dims = 1:2, reduction = "pca")
Seurat::DimPlot(epi, reduction = "pca")
Question: Can you explain the cells distribution along the PCA?
Question(BONUS): The object does already contain a PCA embedding called X_pca. Compare the two embeddings? Do you have potential explanations for the differences?


Exercise 6: Perform a non-linear dimensionality reduction
epi <- Seurat::RunUMAP(epi, dims = 1:25)
Seurat::DimPlot(epi, reduction = "umap")
Question: Can you explain the pattern you observe?
Question(BONUS): As above compare with the existing X_umap embedding.

title: Single Cell: Preprocessing and QC
text:
Save Processed Object

Exercise 7: Save the object for use in the next exercise
saveRDS(epi, file = "../../output/epithelial_bcc_and_normal_preprocessed.rds") # Adapt path to your folder structure!!

title: Single Cell: Integration and Clustering
text:
library(Seurat)
epi <- readRDS("../../output/epithelial_bcc_and_normal_preprocessed.rds") # adapt path to your folder structure!
epi

title: Single Cell: Integration and Clustering
text:
Integration
The previous exercises revealed a batch effect related to the cells origin. Some downstream methods (e.g.¬†differential expression analysis) can directly account for this, but for clustering we need to generate a corrected embedding.

Exercise 1: Integrate data from different origins
# split by identity
epi[["RNA"]] <- split(epi[["RNA"]], f = epi$orig.ident)

# integrate
epi <- Seurat::IntegrateLayers(object = epi, method = "CCAIntegration",
                       orig.reduction = "pca",
                       new.reduction = "integrated",
                       verbose = FALSE)

# re-join layers after integration
epi[["RNA"]] <- SeuratObject::JoinLayers(epi[["RNA"]])
Question: What has changed?


Exercise 2: Visualize the integrated embedding
epi <- Seurat::RunUMAP(epi, dims = 1:30, reduction = "integrated")
Seurat::DimPlot(epi, reduction = "umap")
Question: Why do we recalculate the UMAP? How would rate the integration?

title: Single Cell: Integration and Clustering
text:
Clustering

Exercise 3: Perform the clustering
epi <- Seurat::FindNeighbors(epi, dims = 1:25, reduction = "integrated")
epi <- Seurat::FindClusters(epi, resolution = seq(0.1, 0.8, by=0.1))
head(epi[[]])


Exercise 4 - BONUS: Compare the clustering with the cell type assignments
Try different resolutions and different strategies, e.g.:
table(epi$RNA_snn_res.0.5, epi$`05_subcelltypes`)

epi <- Seurat::SetIdent(epi, value = epi$`05_subcelltypes`)
p1 <- Seurat::DimPlot(epi, group.by = "RNA_snn_res.0.2", label = TRUE, reduction = "umap")
p2 <- Seurat::DimPlot(epi, label = TRUE, reduction = "umap")
p1 + p2
Question: Which resolution should be used?

title: Single Cell: Integration and Clustering
text:
Save Processed Object

Exercise 5: Save the object for use in the next exercise
saveRDS(epi, file = "../../output/epithelial_bcc_and_normal_cell_types.rds") # Adapt path to your folder structure!!

title: Single Cell: The Data Object
text:
In this workshop, we will work with the epithelial single cell transcriptome data from the spatial skin atlas1. The dataset contains cell populations across anatomical sites in healthy human skin and basal cell carcinoma.
Data can be downloaded from the spatial skin atlas website as .h5ad file. This is an AnnData python object. To load it into R you can use the anndataR package. Here we already transformed it into a Seurat object, which can be loaded.

title: Single Cell: The Data Object
text:
The SeuratObject

Exercise1: Load the object
library(Seurat)
epi <- readRDS("data/epithelial_bcc_and_normal_seurat.rds")
epi
The SeuratObject class contains multiple convoluted slots and lists. The figure2 and exercises below will go through the most important slots and show how to navigate the object.



Exercise2: Familiarize yourself with the dataset
head(colnames(epi))  # cell IDs
head(rownames(epi))  # Gene names 

ncol(epi)  # Number of cells
nrow(epi)  # Number of genes
Question: Try to access different of the above slots. What do you find out about the dataset?


Exercise3: Explore the datasets metadata
head(epi@meta.data)
table(epi$`00_conditions`)
Question: What locations are cells from? How many cell types have been assigned?


Exercise4: Identity class labels
In the Seurat framework Identity label or Idents are used to group or categorize cells e.g. sample conditions or cell types. You can view, set or change them. Seurat uses the active identity within its functions, e.g.¬†to calculate variable features etc. Therefore it is important to check the active identity.
epi@active.ident # get active Identity
Idents(epi) <- "04_celltypes" # set active Identity to cell types
Question: How can you set the identity to sub cell types?


Exercise5 (optional): The assay slot
epi@active.assay
Question: What is the active assay? So far we only have one assay. Can you still guess what the active assay is used for?

title: Single Cell: The Data Object
text:
Footnotes


C. Ganier, P. Mazin, G. Herrera-Oropeza, X. Du-Harpur, M. Blakeley, J. Gabriel, A.V. Predeus, B. Cakir, M. Prete, N. Harun, J. Darrigrand, A. Haiser, S. Wyles, T. Shaw, S.A. Teichmann, M. Haniffa, F.M. Watt, & M.D.¬†Lynch, Multiscale spatial mapping of cell populations across anatomical sites in healthy human skin and basal cell carcinoma, Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 121 (2) e2313326120, https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.2313326120 (2024).‚Ü©Ô∏é
From: SIB course Single Cell Transcriptomics, SIB Swiss Institute of Bioinformatics, https://sib-swiss.github.io/single-cell-training/‚Ü©Ô∏é

title: Data Loading
text: In this workshop, we will work with an RNA-seq dataset from the Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO), accession GSE968701. The study examines gene expression in the mouse cerebellum across different developmental time points and biological conditions. The dataset includes a count matrix (raw gene expression values) and sample metadata describing experimental variables such as time and sample ID.

title: Data Loading
text:
Get the Dataset
With the GEOquery package public datasets from GEO can directly be downloaded and loaded as R object (option A) or the counts and metadata files can be downloaded to generate a SummarizedExperiment object from them (option B). Chose only one of the options, but try to answer all questions.

Exercise 1 (option A): Download the dataset from GEO
library(GEOquery)
se <- getGEO("GSE96870", GSEMatrix = TRUE)
se


Exercise 2 (option B): Load the data from csv
Alternatively the data can be downloaded original workshop and read into R. Adapt the path to your file structure!
download.file(
    url = "https://github.com/carpentries-incubator/bioc-rnaseq/raw/main/episodes/data/GSE96870_coldata_cerebellum.csv", 
    destfile = "../../data/GSE96870_coldata_cerebellum.csv"
)

download.file(
    url = "https://github.com/carpentries-incubator/bioc-rnaseq/raw/main/episodes/data/GSE96870_counts_cerebellum.csv", 
    destfile = "../../data/GSE96870_counts_cerebellum.csv"
)

counts <- read.csv("../../data/GSE96870_counts_cerebellum.csv", row.names = 1)
coldata <- read.csv("../../data/GSE96870_coldata_cerebellum.csv", row.names = 1)

dim(counts)
dim(coldata)
Question: How many genes and samples are there?

title: Data Loading
text:
Build the R object

Exercise 3 (option B): Create a SummarizedExperiment object
library(SummarizedExperiment)

se <- SummarizedExperiment(
  assays = list(counts = as.matrix(counts)),
  colData = coldata
)
se
Question: What metadata are available? How many samples are from male mice?


Exercise 4 (optional): Add gene symbols
library(org.Mm.eg.db)
library(AnnotationDbi)

rowData(se)$ENTREZID <- mapIds(
  org.Mm.eg.db,
  keys = rownames(se),
  column = "ENTREZID",
  keytype = "SYMBOL",
  multiVals = "first"
)

head(rowData(se))
Question: Why are some symbols missing (NA)?

title: Data Loading
text:
Explore the data

Exercise 5: Inspect object
nrow(se)   # number of genes
ncol(se)   # number of samples

colData(se)
assay(se)[1:5, 1:5]

table(se$sex)
Question: How many timepoints does the dataset contain?

title: Data Loading
text:
Save Processed Object

Exercise 6: Save the se object for use in the next exercise
saveRDS(se, file = "../../output/se_cerebellum.rds") # Adapt path to your folder structure!!

title: Data Loading
text:
Footnotes


Blackmore, Stephen, et al.¬†‚ÄúInfluenza infection triggers disease in a genetic model of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis.‚Äù Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences 114.30 (2017): E6107-E6116.‚Ü©Ô∏é

title: Single Cell RNA-seq analysis
text:
Exercises



Exercises are based on the single cell data of the Spatial Skin Atlas
Check the publication by Garnier et.al.1 to answer the questions.
The dataset has been published as AnnData object (scverse-python) and was converted into Seurat object for this workshop
Exercises follow a standard Seurat workflow)




C. Ganier, P. Mazin, G. Herrera-Oropeza, X. Du-Harpur, M. Blakeley, J. Gabriel, A.V. Predeus, B. Cakir, M. Prete, N. Harun, J. Darrigrand, A. Haiser, S. Wyles, T. Shaw, S.A. Teichmann, M. Haniffa, F.M. Watt, & M.D.¬†Lynch, Multiscale spatial mapping of cell populations across anatomical sites in healthy human skin and basal cell carcinoma, Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 121 (2) e2313326120, https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.2313326120 (2024).

title: Single Cell RNA-seq analysis
text: The Spatial Skin Atlas

title: Introduction to RNA-Seq
section: The Central Dogma of Molecular Biology
text: The Central Dogma of Molecular Biology

title: Introduction to RNA-Seq
text:
The Reality is more complex ‚Ä¶

RNA is not only a messenger but may have other roles
Most of these elements interacts and regulates one-another
Additional layer of complexity through alternative splicing







mRNA levels ‚Üí a proxy of a proxy of cell physiology

title: Introduction to RNA-Seq
text:
What are we sequencing?
Genomics

Whole genome/exome sequencing¬†(WGS/WES)
Variant calling (SNPs, CNVs, structural variations)

Epigenomics

Bisulphite sequencing :¬†DNA methylation
ATAC-Seq :¬†chromatine¬†opening
ChIP-seq :¬†TF binding sites

title: Introduction to RNA-Seq
text:
What are we sequencing?
Transcriptomics

Total RNA
Poly-A tail selection¬†:¬†focus on mRNA
Ribo depletion: mRNA¬†+¬†ncRNA
5‚Äô/3‚Äô RACE seq : isoform characterization for one gene
single cell RNAseq
Long¬†read¬†RNA sequencing
Spatial Transcriptomics

many more ‚Ä¶

title: Introduction to RNA-Seq
text:
Single cell versus bulk RNA-Seq


Zhu et al.¬†J Transl Med 2024

title: Introduction to RNA-Seq
section: Why bulk RNA-seq still matters in the era of single cell RNA-seq
text:
Why bulk RNA-seq still matters in the era of single cell RNA-seq

 Cost-effectiveness and Scalability

Bulk RNA-seq is orders of magnitude cheaper
Enables large cohorts (hundreds‚Äìthousands of samples)
Essential for population-level or clinical studies

title: Introduction to RNA-Seq
section: Why bulk RNA-seq still matters in the era of single cell RNA-seq
text:
Why bulk RNA-seq still matters in the era of single cell RNA-seq
 Higher Data Quality per Gene

Deeper sequencing per transcript ‚Üí better quantification
Less technical noise, no dropouts
More reliable differential expression results

title: Introduction to RNA-Seq
section: Why bulk RNA-seq still matters in the era of single cell RNA-seq
text:
Why bulk RNA-seq still matters in the era of single cell RNA-seq
 Simplicity and Robustness

Well-established workflows and QC pipelines
Works with degraded/frozen tissues (recent scRNAseq techniques as well)
Relative high reproducibility across labs

title: Introduction to RNA-Seq
section: Why bulk RNA-seq still matters in the era of single cell RNA-seq
text:
Why bulk RNA-seq still matters in the era of single cell RNA-seq
 Biological Interpretability

Average expression is often the relevant measure for tissue-level processes
Examples: Treatment effects on cell line, Developmental stages, Systemic disease states

title: Introduction to RNA-Seq
section: RNAseq data generation - planning your experiment
text:
RNAseq data generation - planning your experiment



How many replicates?
Technical: same RNA extract
Biological: same biological condition
Sequencing depth?
RNA purification?

title: Introduction to RNA-Seq
text:
Biological Replicates







Soneson, C., et al.¬†BMC Bioinformatics 14, 91 (2013)

title: Introduction to RNA-Seq
text:
Sequencing Depth



For DGE analysis: usually aim for 30-40 million reads
Rare events require a much higher sequencing depths
often hard to know in advance

title: Introduction to RNA-Seq
text:
Data Limitations: Sequencing Biases

Fragment length: longer fragments are more likely to be identified
Positional bias: 3‚Äô ends are more likely to be sequenced
Fragment sequence bias: Sequence complexity and GC content influence primer binding

title: Introduction to RNA-Seq
text: Basic Data analysis Pipeline

title: Introduction to RNA-Seq
text:
Input data

Raw data - FASTQ (.fq/.fastq)

contains raw sequencing reads plus quality scores



Reference - FASTA (.fa/.fasta)

contains nucleotide sequences



Annotation file - GTF/GFF (.gff/.gtf)

contains genomic coordinates and features (e.g.¬†genes, exon, ..)

title: Introduction to RNA-Seq
text: Preprocessing

title: Introduction to RNA-Seq
text:
Quality Control

Aim: Identify potential quality issues before analysis


Tools: FastQC, MultiQC

title: Introduction to RNA-Seq
text:
Quality Control


Key Metrics

Per-base quality scores
GC content distribution
Sequence length distribution
Overrepresented sequences

title: Introduction to RNA-Seq
text:
Trimming

Aim: Removal of adapter sequences and low-quality regions


Tools: Trimmomatic, Cutadaptt, fastp

title: Introduction to RNA-Seq
text:
Trimming
Caution: Aggressive trimming (high quality threshold, low length filtering) can have negative impacts on expression quantification (William et al.¬†BMC bioinfo, 2016)

When should we trim?

Variant calling: highly recommended
Expression quantification: no or light trimming
Transcriptome asssembly: highly recommended

title: Introduction to RNA-Seq
text: Read Alignment and Quantification

title: Introduction to RNA-Seq
text:
Read Alignment and Quantification
Aim: Map each read base-by-base to reference genome/transcriptome and count assigned reads

Mapping Tools: STAR, HISAT2, Bowtie2, BWA, ‚Ä¶ (many more)


Quantification tools: featureCounts, HTSeq-count

title: Introduction to RNA-Seq
section: Choosing a reference: Genome vs Transcriptome
text:
Choosing a reference: Genome vs Transcriptome

Genome reference:

Whole genome including splicing junctions
Use Case: Novel transcript discovery, variant calling



Transcriptome reference:

Set of known transcripts (exons only)
Use Case: Fast quantification in well-annotated species

title: Introduction to RNA-Seq
text:
Pseudoalignment

Reads are assigned to transcripts probabilitically
Much faster; no full alignment
Tools: Salmon, Kallisto

title: Introduction to RNA-Seq
text:
Read Normalization

Aim: Adjust for sequencing depth and gene length


Methods:

TPM: Within-sample normalization
FPKM/RPKM: less used today



Important: Some tools for DE analysis (DESeq2, edgeR) have their own normalization implemented

title: Introduction to RNA-Seq
text: Downstream Analysis

title: Enrichment analysis
text:
Motivation



What to do with your list of DE genes?
Interpretation can be difficult with many DE genes
Are our DE genes enriched for a biological function, pathway, TF regulation?

title: Enrichment analysis
section: Mapping genes to gene sets with specific biology
text:
Mapping genes to gene sets with specific biology

Regrouping genes together in meaningful sets

Same pathway
Same location in the cell
Same molecular function

title: Enrichment analysis
text:
The universe matters

Numerous gene set collections available

Gene Ontologies
Reactome
KEGG
MSigDB
Custom gene sets (literature, tentative annotation)
many more ‚Ä¶

title: Enrichment analysis
text:
The universe matters
MsigDB: https://www.gsea-msigdb.org/gsea/msigdb/index.jsp

title: Enrichment analysis
text:
Computing Enrichment


Zhao, K., Rhee Y.R. Trends in Genetics (2023)

title: Enrichment analysis
Enrichment analysis
text:
Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA)

Based on a ranking along a continous measure (e.g.¬†logFC)
No cutoff for DE versus not DE needed
Permutation scheme to test for significance

title: Enrichment analysis
text:
clusterProfiler

ClusterProfiler: user-friendly R package for enrichment analysis
Multiple enrichment detection algorithms, several databases and visulaizations implemented
For more details check out their vignette

title: Enrichment analysis
text:
clusterProfiler


ego <- enrichGO(
  gene          = gene_list,
  OrgDb         = org.Mm.eg.db,
  keyType       = "ENTREZID",
  ont           = "BP",
  pAdjustMethod = "BH",
  qvalueCutoff  = 0.05
)

gse <- gseGO(
  geneList      = gene_list, 
  ont           = "ALL", 
  keyType       = "ENSEMBL", 
  nPerm         = 10000, 
  minGSSize     = 3, 
  maxGSSize     = 800, 
  pvalueCutoff  = 0.05, 
  OrgDb         = org.Mm.eg.db, 
  pAdjustMethod = "none"
)

title: RNAseq-workshop exercises
text:
Overview
These exercises and presentations are part of a two-day RNA-seq data analysis workshop presented at the Young Investigators Symposium of the Skintegrity Network. They provide a hands-on introduction to processing, exploring, and analyzing RNA-seq count data using R and Bioconductor.
The content is adapted and simplified from the Carpentries Incubator course
‚ÄúRNA-seq Analysis with Bioconductor‚Äù
üëâ https://carpentries-incubator.github.io/bioc-rnaseq/
which are highly recommended for further in-depth learning.
The single cell RNAseq exercises are adapted and simplified from the SIB Single Cell Training resources. üëâ https://sib-swiss.github.io/single-cell-training/
Before starting, please ensure that all required R and Bioconductor packages are installed using the script provided in src/install.R or run in an R Terminal:
install.packages(c("BiocManager", "remotes", "dplyr"))
BiocManager::install(c("SummarizedExperiment", "airway", "AnnotationDbi",
                        "org.Mm.eg.db", "DESeq2", "Seurat", "GEOquery",
                        "clusterProfiler", "vsn"))
Basic familiarity with R (loading libraries, running scripts, inspecting objects) is useful, but not required.
Across the exercises, you will:

‚úÖ Load RNA-seq count data

‚úÖ Create Bioconductor data objects

‚úÖ Perform exploratory data analysis and quality control

‚úÖ Run differential expression analysis

‚úÖ Conduct functional enrichment

These exercises are intentionally short and guided to complement the workshop presentation and group discussions.

Type 'demo()' for some demos, 'help()' for on-line help, or
'help.start()' for an HTML browser interface to help.
Type 'q()' to quit R.

Running RStudio



4 panes (views)

R terminal
Script editor
Object browser
File browser






image from hbctrainings - Intro to R

title: R Basics
text:
R scripts and extenstions


Why?

Re-running code

Debugging !

Tracking code/execution
Sharing code



Flavors

.R

plain R code (comments can be marked by #)
Rscript my-script.R

.rmd or .RMarkdown

mix of R code chunks with output and markdown (text)
can be compiled (rendered) into html or pdf

.qmd

‚òùÔ∏è with diverse code chunks (e.g.¬†python)

title: R Basics
text: Demo RStudio

title: R Basics
text:
R Basic concepts - Syntax

# starts a comment
<- is used for variable assignment
= is used for argument assignment

Example
# Show some examples
foo <- c(2,4,5)
bar <- vec_fun(arg1=foo)

title: R Basics
text:
R Basic concepts - Packages
‚ÄúBase R‚Äù provides you with core functionalities, but most code is shared as R package/library.
Anyone can write an R package and use by themselves or share. Standard ways of distributing packages are github or package repositories such as CRAN or Bioconductor

title: R Basics
text:
Install a package

# build-in install
install.packages("BiocManager")

# BiocManager install 
BiocManager::install("SummarizedExperiment")

# pak package manager
pak::pkg_install("tibble")

# Load package
library(DESeq2)
 ‚ùó Most Bioconductor packages can not be installed via install.packages(), but only with BiocManager or pak.

title: R Basics
text:
Bioconductor

Ecosytem for bioinformatics R packages (origin in genomics üß¨)
Standardized data formats and classes (interoperability)
Versioning and testing
Documentation and standardized workflows (vignettes üìÑ)

title: R Basics
text:
SummarizedExperiment class



Standardized structure (most Bioconductor packages use this or one of its derivatives)
Link between data matrix (or matrices) and metadata
Aims to keeps data and metadata in sync (e.g.¬†keep metadat in order after filtering)

title: R Basics
text:
SummarizedExperiment example

library(SummarizedExperiment)
data(airway, package="airway")
se <- airway
se
class: RangedSummarizedExperiment 
dim: 200 6 
metadata(0):
assays(1): counts
rownames: NULL
rowData names(1): feature_id
colnames(6): A B ... E F
colData names(1): Treatment

title: Functional Analysis
text:
Preprocessing
Why?

Sequencing depth varies across libraries
High dynamic range of expression
High number of genes vs low number of samples

What?

Filtering of low abundance genes
Normalization

Library size
Gene length

title: Functional Analysis
text:
Filtering

Simple: Keep genes with more than X counts
# Keep genes/rows that have > 5 total counts 
se <- se[rowSums(assay(se, "counts")) > 5, ]

Advanced: Keep genes with more than X counts in at least Y samples
# Keep genes/rows that have > 3 counts in at least 3 sample
se[rowSums(assay(se, "counts") > 3) >= 3, ]

title: Functional Analysis
text:
Filtering - Considerations

Easier Interpretation: Not or lowly expressed genes are unlikely to be biological meaningful
More Power: Filtering reduces the number of statistical tests (multiple testing)
Better Model: More roboust estimation of mean-variance relationship


Try different approaches and check the remaining gene number and type.

title: Functional Analysis
text:
Normalization - Gene Length


Making counts comparable across features (genes)

title: Functional Analysis
text:
Normalization - Sequencing Depth


Making counts comparable across samples

title: Functional Analysis
text:
Normalization - Approaches




by library size (using gene length and sequencing depth)
by distribution (group genes with similar expression)
by testing (identify non-DE genes for normalization)
using controls (e.g.¬†spike-ins, house-keepig genes)
variance-stabilizing transformation (stable variance across different means)

title: Functional Analysis
text:
Normalization method
Description
Accounted factors
Recommendations for use




CPM (counts per million)
counts scaled by total number of reads
sequencing depth
gene count comparisons between replicates; NOT for within sample or DE analysis


TPM (transcripts per kilobase million)
counts per length of transcript (kb) per million reads mapped
sequencing depth and gene length
gene count comparisons within a sample or sample group; NOT for DE analysis


RPKM/FPKM (reads/fragments per kilobase of exon per million reads/fragments mapped)
similar to TPM
sequencing depth and gene length
gene count comparisons within a sample; NOT for between sample or DE analysis




Table from hbctraing:Intro-to-DGE

title: Functional Analysis
text:
Normalization method
Description
Accounted factors
Recommendations for use




DESeq2‚Äôs median of ratios [1]
counts divided by sample-specific size factors determined by median ratio of gene counts relative to geometric mean per gene
sequencing depth and RNA composition
gene count comparisons between samples and for DE analysis; NOT for within sample comparisons


EdgeR‚Äôs trimmed mean of M values (TMM) [2]
uses a weighted trimmed mean of the log expression ratios between samples
sequencing depth and RNA composition
gene count comparisons between samples and for DE analysis; NOT for within sample comparisons




Table from hbctraing:Intro-to-DGE

title: Functional Analysis
text:
Recommendations

Under the hood most tools use a mix of different normalisations (e.g.¬†DESeq2::estimateSizeFactors())
Standard tools for DGE (DESeq2, edgeR, Limma etc) use raw counts
For visualisation (PCA, clustering, heatmaps etc), use VST or RLOG
For own analysis with gene length correction, use TPM (maybe geTMM?)

title: Functional Analysis
text:
Exploratory Data Analysis


Inspect your data and identify and try to understand general pattern


Examples

Clustering
Principal Component Ananlysis

title: Functional Analysis
text:
Principal Component Analysis




Reduce complexity and understand main driver of variance
Map data into low dimensional space (linear dimensionality reduction)
Interpretable

title: Functional Analysis
text:
Principal Component Analysis
 First dimensions represent main axis of variance in data


Czarnewski, P., Parigi, S.M., Sorini, C. et al.¬†Conserved transcriptomic profile between mouse and human colitis allows unsupervised patient stratification. Nat Commun 10, 2892 (2019). https://doi.org/10.1038/s41467-019-10769-x

title: Functional Analysis
text:
Principal Component Analysis



from https://glowingpython.blogspot.com/2011/07/pca-and-image-compression-with-numpy.html

title: Functional Analysis
text:
Clustering

Classify/group samples -> understand sample similarities
Understand pattern
Identify outlier
Try different clustering methods and check cluster roboustness

title: Functional Analysis
text:
Differential Expression


Understanding systematic changes between experimental groups or conditions





Identify genes with differential expression pattern using between- and within-condition variability
Requires biological replicates (multiple sample from each condition)
Multiple R packages exist specific for DE analysis (e.g.¬†edgeR, DESeq2)





Image from hbctraing:Intro-to-DGE

title: Functional Analysis
text:
Differential Expression Analysis
RNAseq Data Challenges:

Limited number of replicates per group
Mean-variance dependency
Skewed count distribution



Image from hbctraing:Intro-to-DGE

title: Functional Analysis
text:
DESeq2




Statistical modeling

model RNA-seq counts as negative binomial distribution
borrow information from genes with similar expression pattern to estimate gene-wise dispersion
Fit a Generalized linear model for each gene and run Wald test





Image from hbctraing:Intro-to-DGE

title: Functional Analysis
text:
The Design Matrix and Contrasts

Design matrix

Describes the model coefficients
Include variable of interest and all variables to account for

designFormula = ~ sex + time

Contrasts

Describes the comparison of interest (reference variable and levels to compare)

results(dds, contrast = c("time", "Day8", "Day0"))

title: Functional Analysis
text:
DE Results



Heatmap


Volcano plot

text:
Format


 

Presentations: background, theory, examples
Exercises: R-code + questions
RECAP: group discussion + results


Ask questions at anytime!

title: RNA-seq analysis
text:
Resources


https://almutlue.github.io/RNAseq-workshop/


Help

Ask one of us!
Discuss with your neighbour!
Check the vignettes (DESeq2 and Seurat)
Ask an AI tool of your choice!


https://github.com/almutlue/RNAseq-workshop

title: Single Cell: Differential Expression
text:
library(Seurat)
epi <- readRDS("../../output/epithelial_bcc_and_normal_cell_types.rds") # adapt path to your folder structure!
epi

title: Single Cell: Differential Expression
text:
Differentially expressed Genes

Exercise 1: DE genes between cluster (aka cell type marker)
library(dplyr)

epi <- Seurat::SetIdent(epi, value = epi$`05_subcelltypes`)
marker <- Seurat::FindAllMarkers(epi,  min.pct = 0.25,
                                   only.pos = TRUE)

top_marker <- marker |>
  group_by(cluster) |>
  top_n(1, avg_log2FC)

FeaturePlot(epi, features = top_marker$gene)
Question: Plot different marker genes, e.g.¬†top 10 marker for a certain cell type. Do the marker genes support cell type assignments as done in the original study?


Exercise 2: DE between conditions
Testing for differential expressed genes across conditions within the same cell type.
# Create a metadata column with the origin and cell type info
epi$celltype.origin <- paste(epi$`05_subcelltypes`, epi$orig.ident, sep = "_")
Idents(epi) <- "celltype.origin"

# Calculate DE genes for one specific cell type and origin
de_div_K <- FindMarkers(epi, ident.1 = "Dividing K_bcc", ident.2 = "Dividing K_ife", verbose = FALSE)
head(de_div_K, n = 10)
Question: Explore differential expressed genes for different cell types.
Question: Do you notice something about the p-values?

title: Enrichment analysis
text:
Load the results produced in exercise 4 (skip if it‚Äôs still in your environment).
res <- readRDS("../../output/de_sex_time.rds")  # adapt path to your folder structure!

title: Enrichment analysis
text:
DE gene list

Exercise 1: Load DE genes for overrepresentation analysis
gene_list <- rownames(res[which(res$padj < 0.05), ])
head(gene_list)
Question: How many significant genes do we have for enrichment?

title: Enrichment analysis
text:
Overrepresentation Analysis

Exercise 2: Perform GO overrepresentation analysis
library(clusterProfiler)
library(org.Mm.eg.db)

ego <- enrichGO(gene          = gene_list,
                OrgDb         = org.Mm.eg.db,
                keyType       = "SYMBOL",
                ont           = "BP",
                pAdjustMethod = "BH",
                qvalueCutoff  = 0.05)
ego
Question: How many GO terms are significant?

title: Enrichment analysis
text:
Visualization

Exercise 3: Plot top enriched GO terms
barplot(ego, showCategory = 10)

title: Differential Expression Analysis
text:
Load the SummarizedExperiment object created earlier (skip if it‚Äôs still in your environment).
se <- readRDS("../../output/se_cerebellum.rds")  # adapt path to your folder structure!
se <- se[rowSums(assay(se, "counts")) > 5, ]
se

title: Differential Expression Analysis
text:
The experimental design

Exercise 1: Create the DESeqDataSet object and define the experiment
The DESeqDataSet object has a design parameter to specify what conditions shall be compared.
dds <- DESeqDataSet(se, design = ~ sex + time)
Question: How can you interpret this design formula? What is compared here?

title: Differential Expression Analysis
text:
Differential expression analysis

Exercise 2: Run the DESeq pipeline
Note: This step estimates size factors, dispersions, and fits the model.
dds <- DESeq(dds)

title: Differential Expression Analysis
text:
Results

Exercise 3: Extract results for the comparison
res <- results(dds)
summary(res)
Question: How many genes are significantly differentially expressed (padj < 0.05)?

title: Differential Expression Analysis
text:
Top DE genes

Exercise 4: View the top differentially expressed genes.
head(res[order(res$padj), ])
Question: Which gene has the smallest adjusted p-value?

title: Differential Expression Analysis
text:
Visualization

Exercise 5: Create a basic volcano plot
plot(res$log2FoldChange, -log10(res$padj),
     xlab = "Log2 Fold Change", ylab = "-Log10 adj p-value")

title: Differential Expression Analysis
text:
Save Processed Object

Exercise 6: Save the results for enricment analysis
saveRDS(res, file = "../../output/de_sex_time.rds") # Adapt path to your folder structure!!

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Quality Control
text:
Load the SummarizedExperiment object created earlier (skip if it‚Äôs still in your environment).
se <- readRDS("../../output/se_cerebellum.rds")  # adapt path to your folder structure!
se

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Quality Control
text:
Gene Filtering

Exercise 1: Remove genes with very low counts across all samples
keep <- rowSums(assay(se)) > 5
se_filt <- se[keep, ]
nrow(se) 
nrow(se_filt)
Question: How many genes were removed?

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Quality Control
text:
Normalization

Exercise 2: Transform the data
Check the variance across genes with different mean counts. The variance-stabilizing transformation was developed as part of the DESeq2 package to account for this variance-mean relationship. The DESeq2 package uses the DESeqDataSet as underlying object class. The structure is an extension of the SummarizedExperiment class.
library(DESeq2)
library(vsn)
# Generate the object
dds <- DESeqDataSet(se_filt, design = ~ 1)

# Plot the mean sd relationship
meanSdPlot(assay(dds), ranks = FALSE)

# Transform the data
vsd <- vst(dds)

# Plot the transformed data
meanSdPlot(assay(vsd), ranks = FALSE)

title: Exploratory Data Analysis and Quality Control
text:
Data Visualization

Exercise 3: Perform a principal component analysis
pca <- prcomp(t(assay(vsd)))
plot(pca$x[,1], pca$x[,2],
     xlab = "PC1", ylab = "PC2")
text(pca$x[,1], pca$x[,2], labels = colnames(vsd), pos = 3)
Question: Do samples cluster by any known variable (e.g., time)?

title: R Basics Exercises
text: This section introduces essential R skills needed for the RNA-seq workshop. Explanations will be covered in the presentation; here we focus on practical steps.

title: R Basics Exercises
text:
R and RStudio

Exercise 1: Open a project
Open RStudio and create a new R Project in a folder called rnaseq_workshop.


Exercise 2: Try the Console
In the Console, type:
2 + 5
"Hello, RNAseq!"


Exercise 3: Create and run a script

Create a new R script called intro.R.
Add the following code:

# My first script
3 * 4

Run the line using Ctrl/Cmd + Enter.

title: R Basics Exercises
text:
Objects and Classes

Exercise 4: Create some basic objects
genes <- 20000
sample_name <- "Sample1"
is_control <- TRUE


Exercise 5: Check object classes
class(genes)
class(sample_name)
class(is_control)


Exercise 6: Create and explore a vector
counts <- c(10, 50, 200, 0)
length(counts)

title: R Basics Exercises
text:
Bioconductor

Exercise 7: Load the package
library(SummarizedExperiment)


Exercise 8: Load example dataset from airway package
The airway package contains some example RNAseq data that come as RangedSummarieExperiment (a derivation of the SummarizedExperiment class) object.
# Load the data
data(airway, package="airway")

# assign the data to the variable se
se <- airway


Exercise 9: Explore the object
You can use the following functions to access different parts of the object. Try to answer the following questions: 1. What is the advantage of combining these different parts of the data (e.g.¬†metadata, count data)? 2. How can you downsample the object to the first 10 features? Check the vignette or ask a LLM, if you need help. 3. [BONUS] Can you guess the experimental setup from exploring the object?
se
assay(se)
colData(se)
rowData(se)


Exercise 10: Determine dataset size
dim(se)      # rows = genes/features, cols = samples
nrow(se)     # number of rows (features)
ncol(se)     # number of columns (samples)
